Walmart which receives large subsidies in tax credits and food stamps so that it can pay less than a living wage to its employees would also be hit.

Considering the federal gov't is one of the nations largest employers, the cut off of cash flowing will trickle down everywhere. Wealth does not trickle down. Hard times pour down on the poor and middle class.

I think what is at issue is that a "miracle' (ala the religious superstition) isn't going to happen.

The point is with a disease or debilitating condition that may not be permanent any improvement in the athlete's condition would be gradual overtime thus whilst she may be considered disabled now in 3 months she might have 10% more use of her legs, in 6 months that might be 30% more use and less disability......would anybody but the athlete notice after she had already been deemed eligible?
Would she admit to an improvement in her condition and withdraw from competition?

If a 'permanent' disability is the agreed baseline for the paralympics then one would consider a medical opinion of permanent disability to be a fair and unambiguous condition of eligibility.

Agreed. And if the committee is "just following a rule," that rule needs to be changed. Both Ms. Arlen and her doctor are being punished for optimistically looking to some future day when she might see some improvement in her condition. The rules for participation should focus solely on the nature and extent of disability at the time of competition.

The undisputed facts are that she can't use her legs at present, and she is not "faking it," whatever that means. That should be the beginning and end of the story.

I suspect that if that great day in the future ever arrives, Ms. Arlen will be ecstatic to learn that she has lost her eligibility. For now, let her swim.

LaContra, I think you may be conflating permanent and partial. One can have a permanent partial disability. A 10% or even 30% increase in leg use may make her disability partial, but no less permanent. It is not clear to me from the article that "permanent" is synonymous with "total."

That said, I would give her the benefit of the doubt and presume she would be honest about her condition, were it to improve. Additionally, she is a swimmer and as one can see from the underwater photo, it would be most difficult for her to use her legs unnoticed.

Why punish her now for something that may or may not happen in the future?  Clearly she is disabled now - let her compete as disabled until the miracle occurs that changes her status. Give her the opportunity to make the most of the abilities she has while she can.

@IMC

"... social animals of all stripes do it. "

What? Can you give an example of these "social animals" and their wealth accumulation? Even humans, pre-agriculture, were pretty much egalitarian. They were territorial and fought over that, but as the "wealthiest" person was likely to be the "medicine man/woman" who was perceived to have power over life and death, not possessions. As people weren't nearly as settled prior to agriculture, they had few possessions to begin with and other social animals have none that I can think of. Civilization (as signified by the invention of agriculture) allowed people to stay in one place, form permanent settlements, specialize their activities, and begin to accumulate wealth and its very important concomitant, POWER.

There’s a whole lotta complaining going on in here, a whole lotta anger directed, rightfully so, at a small cabal that manipulates the grand majority of wealth in this nation. And as much as everyone seems to hate them, We, the People continue to aspire to be there. Just look at Powerball sales.

I would ask a different question. I would ask, “where are we going wrong as a nation that we cannot breed a class of affluent people with a social conscience?”

This is not a frivolous question; it’s a serious one that needs to be addressed lest we are doomed to repeat the ToonTown CongressClown convention and I would begin with a simple idea: mandatory national service. To teach class-free cooperation and diverse responsibility, we need an environment where being citizen of these here United States comes with specific responsibility. It’s not enough to pay taxes; all our kids, regardless of race, class, ethnicity, education, height, weight, hair or eye color must perform two years of national service. They are required to tend to the nation to which they belong. No one gets into college or a military academy until they finish their compulsories.

Creating a new melting pot where all the kids get the same pay starting in the same trenches is not the worst idea in the world. If nothing more, it would introduce the junior Benmosches to rest of We, the People.

It tougher to dismiss the "others" when you've shared sweat equity.

I teach at an economically diverse public school in Oakland where our district focus this year is argumentative writing, reading of complex text, and academic discourse in all grades. We structure our curriculum around multi-month science and social studies units, and integrate as much of the curriculum as possible. In addition, half the school day is taught in Spanish.

My daughter attends a public school in a nearby district that seems equally inspired (although, alas, without the Spanish).

While I agree that the test-prepping frenzy was common in lower-performing schools until recently (such as the previous school I taught at), many other public schools are truly inspired. And from what I've seen so far, the adoption of the Common Core standards is likely to improve the quality of education in all public schools.

Don't be so quick to write off public schools.

I live on the South Fork of the Nooksack River (although it should be called a tine because there are three forks in the Nooksack River) north of Seattle but not quite in B.C. We tube on my fork of the river. This year I saw something which is usually seen only on the Nature channel, an eagle swoop down on the river and snared a salmon and flew away. I saw this because I was tubing silently down the middle of the river.
25 miles away in Bellingham the coal trains are starting to come through at very regular intervals every morning. Our natural beauty cannot survive the presence of coal trains and their polluting poison. I live within 3 miles of an Indian reservation whose way of life cannot survive pollution. This may not mean anything but I hope it will, everday my golden retriever and I (both of us are retired) walk miles of this river and she without a leash--it would be really nice if we could save this way of life for everyone's grandchildren

The Estates General preceding the French Revolution failed because the peasants could afford to pay no more in taxes, the nobles refused as always to pay any in the chronic revenue problem of the monarchy. The fabulously wealthy agreed the king had a problem, but not them.

In the end, the French general assembly, as it became, moved one way, then another and eventually the Great Majority shifted toward removing the monarch, eventually executed with his wife. Somehow, the nobles did not realize they had lost a guardian, at least not until the Reign of Terror began. As usual, in the end it consumed its own, e.g Robespierre, but it also sent perhaps 17,000 to the guillotine and another 25,000 or so summarily executed.

In the end the nobles who were executed by and large had it coming and then some. Many of those not executed were a more amiable and less crass lot, held in high regard by people in a state of national anger. Of course after Napoleon, some of the old school ancient regime tried to resume their old ways, but did not last long.

Sometimes a national paroxysm is necessary to cut down the parasitic 1 percent. I would favor, for instance, exiling the Koch brothers to Bangladash or Somalia, minus all of their loot. It is very sad what extreme wealth does to human behavior. I have a dear friend who I have known since he was 14. I worked with his dad and then with him when he finished college. We shared a small studio and had many good times and creative moments.

In 1992, he started in an ad bureau, eventually took over the firm, then sold it out to a US corporation for $200 million in 2000. He is still my friend today, but his views about life and economics have changed so much that no matter which of his 4 homes he occupies, he donates a great deal of time advising a political party which is firmly based on libertarian, monetarist ideals of tax breaks and deregulated markets and claims that public spending is inefficient. Maybe one day when he is near death he will look about him and wonder where all his true friends are. Extreme wealth is unnatural and can be a terminal condition.
